questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The pain began 6 hours ago and has become more severe over the last 2 hours. She noticed vaginal spotting this morning. Past medical history is significant for two rounds of ovulation induction therapy in the past six months. Her last menstrual period was six weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Transabdominal ultrasound shows free fluid in the pelvis and does not detect an intrauterine gestational sac. Emergency exploratory laparoscopy is performed, and the mesosalpinx is incised to remove the pathological specimen involved. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histological examination of the specimen?

choices.text: Simple cuboidal epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
This patient presented with symptoms of amenorrhea, pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, and history of ovulation induction therapy. She most likely has a ruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.    

Ectopic pregnancy is an extrauterine pregnancy and commonly occurs in the uterine tubes. It should be suspected in women of reproductive age with risk factors for a tubal pregnancy, including the previous history of tubal pregnancy, IUD use, sterilization, and history of tubal disease. Laboratory investigations would reveal a rising beta hCG level, and imaging could reveal an extra ovarian adnexal mass/ extrauterine gestational sac on transvaginal ultrasound.    

The fallopian tubes are situated in the upper margin of the broad ligament of the uterus and are divided anatomically into 4 divisions; the infundibulum, the ampulla, the isthmus, and the intramural or interstitial part of the tube. The isthmus forms the medial one-third of the tube. The ampulla forms the lateral two-thirds and is the site of fertilization. The infundibulum forms the lateral end of the uterine tube and is attached to the tubal pole of the ovary.    

Due to its close proximity to the ovary, ovarian torsion or rupture are often considered in the differential diagnosis of an acute abdomen in a woman of reproductive age. However, these differentials are unlikely to cause abnormal vaginal bleeding or amenorrhea. A transvaginal ultrasound can further aid in distinguishing ovarian pathologies from a tubal pregnancy. Ovarian torsion on a pelvic ultrasound would reveal an adnexal mass with the absent flow on a doppler USG.  



Option Analysis

✅ Simple ciliated columnar epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Simple cuboidal epithelium :
Incorrect: Simple cuboidal epithelium covers the epithelial surface of the ovary. Although ovarian torsion would necessitate an oophorectomy, it is unlikely to present with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding.   
❌ Simple squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: The peritoneum is lined with simple squamous epithelium (mesothelium) and is rarely the site of an ectopic pregnancy.  
❌ Stratified squamous non keratinized epithelium :
Incorrect: The vagina and the ectocervix are lined with stratified squamous non keratinized epithelium and cervical ectopic pregnancies are rare. A tubal ectopic pregnancy is much more likely to be encountered.   
❌ Simple cuboidal epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands :
Incorrect: Mature teratomas on histology reveal simple cuboidal ovarian epithelium with tissues from multiple germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm). They are commonly found in women between the ages of 20-30 and can cause ovarian torsion. Ovarian torsion is unlikely to present with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the office for a routine prenatal appointment at 28 weeks of gestation. The pregnancy has been uneventful, and she has been compliant with prenatal care. During the past week, she has been feeling a severe throbbing headache, with minimal response to acetaminophen. Medical history is unremarkable, and she has no history of migraines. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. Review of medical records at 24 weeks of gestation shows blood pressure of 135/80. Which of the following would prompt further evaluation in this patient?

choices.text: Dilatation of the ureters and renal pelvis on ultrasound
Elevation of liver enzymes 2 times the upper limit
Proteinuria of 200 mg/day in a 24-hour urine specimen

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a new onset of hypertension and severe headache resistant to pharmacological therapy after 20 weeks gestation, raising concerns for preeclampsia.  

Preeclampsia is a multisystem progressive disorder defined as a new onset of hypertension and proteinuria or significant end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks gestation. The disorder is caused by placental and maternal vascular dysfunction and typically resolves after delivery. The pathogenesis involves abnormal development of the uteroplacental circulation that results in placental hypoperfusion and adverse pregnancy outcomes, including preeclampsia, second trimester fetal death, abruptio placentae, intrauterine growth restriction, and preterm labor. On examination, preeclampsia is associated with a variety of manifestations such as generalized hyperreflexia or clonus, amaurosis fugax, epigastric pain, oliguria, peripheral or pulmonary edema, and even stroke. Cardinal risk factors for developing preeclampsia include past or family history of preeclampsia, nulliparity, preexisting diabetes, chronic hypertension, obesity, and multiple gestation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Dilatation of the ureters and renal pelvis on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Hydroureter and hydronephrosis are physiologic changes of pregnancy that can be seen in up to 80% of pregnant women and are considered benign features. These changes have been attributed to hormonal effects (progesterone relaxes the urinary tract), mechanical compression from the enlarging uterus, and intrinsic changes within the ureteral wall. 
❌ Lower extremity edema :
Incorrect: Water retention, with edema of the ankles and legs, is a physiological phenomenon seen in many pregnant women, whether or not they have preeclampsia. However, a sudden weight gain (e.g., >5 lb [2.3 kg]/week) and/or facial edema can be signs of preeclampsia and should prompt further evaluation. 
❌ Air hunger:
Incorrect: Dyspnea (also known as "air hunger") is common during the course of normal pregnancy, and can be seen in up to 70% of women. The exact mechanism is not clear but may be related to an increase in abdominal girth and/or upward pressure on the diaphragm as well as progesterone-induced hyperventilation. Pulmonary edema, however, is consistent with findings of preeclampsia or peripartum cardiomyopathy and would prompt further evaluation.  
✅ Elevation of liver enzymes 2 times the upper limit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proteinuria of 200 mg/day in a 24-hour urine specimen:
Incorrect: Normal urinary protein excretion is less than 100 mg/day. During pregnancy, levels rising from normal levels to 150 to 200 mg/day in the third trimester is considered normal. However, urinary protein excretion greater than 300 mg/day is considered abnormal and should prompt further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old primigravid woman comes to the office at 18 weeks gestation due to palpitations and pelvic pressure. She has been consistent with prenatal care. She is following a healthy diet and takes prenatal vitamins daily. She does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient’s skin is moist and warm. Uterus size is consistent with 22 weeks of gestation. When the patient is holding her hands stretched, a mild tremor is noted. The thyroid gland is normal to palpation and nontender. Laboratory tests show hCG concentrations of 110,000 mIU/mL. TSH is 0.1 μU/mL. An abdominal ultrasound is obtained and shown below.  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Further evaluation would most likely reveal which of the following karyotypes?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tremors, suppressed TSH) and size-date discrepancy. The hyperthyroidism is most likely caused by extremely high levels of hCG, which has weak thyroid-stimulating activity. The ultrasound results show a classic "Swiss cheese pattern," favoring the diagnosis of molar pregnancy.  

Hydatidiform mole (also known as a molar pregnancy or mole), is a premalignant disease that is caused by aberrant fertilization. A molar pregnancy can be categorized as a complete mole or partial mole, which differ by pathogenesis, gross morphology, histopathology, karyotype, and risk of malignancy. Complete moles are formed by the duplication of the haploid genes of a single sperm following fertilization of an empty ovum and therefore are diploid 46,XX. Less commonly, 46,XY karyotype may occur due to dispermic fertilization of an empty ovum.    

Partial moles occur due to fertilization of a normal ovum by two sperm and therefore are triploid (69,XXX, 69,XXY, or 69,XYY). Compared to complete mole, hCG levels are typically far lower in partial moles, and uterine size is often normal. Additionally, hyperemesis gravidarum, hyperthyroidism, and theca lutein cysts are less common since these features are caused by severely elevated b-hCG levels. On ultrasound, both conditions are characterized by ultrasound appearance of cystic spaces ("Swiss cheese pattern"), but fetal parts may be seen in a partial mole.    

Although benign, molar pregnancy increases the risk for invasive disease (e.g., choriocarcinoma, invasive mole). The risk is higher with a complete mole. Treatment is evacuation, which is both therapeutic and diagnostic. Monitoring hCG following treatment is required to detect signs of invasive disease. At the same time, contraceptives are used for several months during the monitoring phase to prevent confusion with normal pregnancies.  



Option Analysis

✅ 46, XX:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 46, XO:
Incorrect: This karyotype is consistent with Turner syndrome, a genetic condition characterized by partly or completely missing an X chromosome in a female. Ultrasound findings in utero of Turner syndrome include large septated cystic hygroma, total body lymphangiectasia (hydrops fetalis), cardiac defects (e.g. coarctation of the aorta), and nuchal thickening. In contrast, this patient’s ultrasound does not show a fetus. 
❌ 69, XXX:
Incorrect: Partial moles occur due to fertilization of a normal ovum by two sperm and therefore are triploid (69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY). Compared to complete moles, hCG levels are typically far lower, and uterine size is often normal. Additionally, hyperemesis gravidarum, hyperthyroidism, and theca lutein cysts are less common, since these features are seen in patients with severely elevated b-hCG levels. On ultrasound, both conditions are characterized by ultrasound appearance of cystic spaces ("Swiss cheese pattern"), but fetal parts may be seen in partial moles. 
❌ 69, XYY:
Incorrect: Partial moles occur due to fertilization of a normal ovum by two sperm and therefore are triploid (69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY). Compared to complete moles, hCG levels are typically far lower, and uterine size is often normal. Additionally, hyperemesis gravidarum, hyperthyroidism, and theca lutein cysts are less common, since these features are seen in patients with severely elevated b-hCG levels. On ultrasound, both conditions are characterized by ultrasound appearance of cystic spaces ("Swiss cheese pattern"), but fetal parts may be seen in partial moles.  
❌ 47, XY,+21:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Down syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of all or part of the third copy of chromosome 21. Sonographic findings of Down syndrome include endocardial cushion defects, VSD, duodenal atresia, and thickened nuchal fold.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 30 weeks gestation comes to the labor and delivery unit due to painful contractions for the past several hours. She did not receive any prenatal care. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 135/84 mmHg. The fetal ultrasound shows an amniotic fluid index of 24 cm (normal 8-18) with the single deepest pocket measuring 9 cm. She denies any gush of fluid. Pelvic examination reveals a uterus size consistent with 34 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with minimal prenatal care is presenting with preterm labor and size-date discrepancy, most likely due to high amniotic fluid levels. Among the answers above, only esophageal atresia, which impairs the fetus' ability to swallow fluid, will result in a high amniotic fluid index.

During the first trimester, the amniotic fluid volume is derived from the maternal compartment, fetal secretions, and the placenta. During the second trimester, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid. The amniotic fluid volume reflects the balance between fluid production and absorption. Therefore, any condition that results in an increase in fetal urine production or a decrease in fetal swallowing can result in polyhydramnios, which is defined as an excessive volume of amniotic fluid. Polyhydramnios should be suspected when uterine size is large for gestational age. The diagnosis is made prenatally by ultrasound examination showing an amniotic fluid index ≥24 cm or a single deepest pocket of ≥8 cm.



Option Analysis

❌ Uteroplacental insufficiency:
Incorrect: Uteroplacental insufficiency results in oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid index) and uterine size that is less than expected for gestational age. Low amniotic fluid is associated with Potter sequence, which includes severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia.
❌ Posterior urethral valve :
Incorrect: Posterior urethral valves, obstructions of the lower urinary tract (e.g. urethral atresia), and intrinsic renal disorders (e.g., renal agenesis, polycystic renal disease) will result in reduced amniotic fluid production. Low amniotic fluid is associated with Potter sequence, which includes severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia.
✅ Esophageal atresia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Renal agenesis:
Incorrect: Renal agenesis, intrinsic renal disorders, and obstruction of the lower urinary tract (e.g., posterior urethral valve, urethral atresia) result in reduced amniotic fluid production. Low amniotic fluid is associated with Potter sequence, which includes severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia.
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use :
Incorrect: NSAIDs, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and trastuzumab use during pregnancy is associated with oligohydramnios, not polyhydramnios. It is thought that NSAIDs induce renal antidiuretic responses, reduce renal blood flow, and are therefore associated with decreased fetal urine flow.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, comes to the labor and delivery triage at 37 weeks gestation due to mild vaginal bleeding for the past 2 hours. She has not had any pain but has had occasional, non-painful contractions. She did not receive prenatal care but states that she took prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy. The patient’s firstborn was delivered via cesarean section. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears comfortable. The uterus is soft and nontender. Streaks of blood are seen in the vaginal vault with no active bleeding. The fetus is in a vertex position. The fetal heart rate is 150 bpm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with painless vaginal bleeding in the 3rd trimester, favoring the diagnosis of placenta previa.    

Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implantation over the internal cervical os, covering all or part of the cervix. The classic presentation is painless late-pregnancy vaginal bleeding. Normally, the placenta implants in the upper uterus, and although it is unclear why it implants in the lower uterus in placenta previa, one hypothesis suggests that areas of suboptimal vascularity in the upper uterine cavity from previous damage (e.g. surgery) promotes implantation in the lower part. Significant risk factors include previous cesarean deliveries, previous uterine surgery, multiple gestations, and previous placenta previa. It is important to note that the presence of pain and tender uterus makes the diagnosis of placenta previa unlikely.  

The vast majority of placenta previas are identified on ultrasound examination before 20 weeks gestation and typically resolve spontaneously before delivery. In asymptomatic patients < 37 weeks of gestation, management includes follow up with transvaginal ultrasound. If the previa resolves, routine prenatal care can resume. In unstable patients with severe bleeding or evidence of fetal distress, emergent cesarean surgery is indicated. In patients whose previa does not resolve, cesarean section is the preferred method of delivery to avoid postpartum hemorrhage.



Option Analysis

❌ False labor :
Incorrect: "False labor," also known as Braxton-Hicks contractions, refers to regular or irregular painful contractions without cervical dilation. This patient had occasional, non-painful contractions, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ True labor:
Incorrect: True labor is characterized by progressive painful contractions and cervical dilation that occur at the latent phase of labor every 3-5 minutes. A small amount of blood often accompanies labor and is known as “bloody show”. This patient has had irregular, non-painful contractions, and her bleeding has stopped, making this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Placental abruption :
Incorrect: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall that occurs after 20 weeks gestation. Typical presentation includes acute onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding (although bleeding may be concealed), uterine contractions, and uterine tenderness.
✅ Placenta previa :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Placenta accreta :
Incorrect: Placenta accreta refers to a placenta that attaches to the myometrium without penetrating it. Placenta accreta presents as a life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs after delivery when manual placental separation is attempted. This patient has not yet delivered, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office due to vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. The patient’s last menstrual cycle was 6 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her male partner of 2 years, and they have been using the withdrawal method as contraception. Medical history is unremarkable other than an episode of pelvic pain 2 years ago that resolved spontaneously without treatment. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Serum hCG is positive, measuring 1200 mIU/mL. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty, normal-appearing uterus and no other abnormalities. Physical examination shows mild lower right adnexal tenderness but is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Obstruction of blood flow to the ovary

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, an empty uterus on vaginal ultrasound, and positive hCG, raising concerns for ectopic pregnancy. The history of pelvic pain that resolved spontaneously implies pelvic inflammatory disease that caused tubal scarring, which puts her at risk for ectopic pregnancy.  

The first step in management in any hemodynamically stable female patient of reproductive age with abdominal pain is to obtain urine/serum hCG. If positive, the next step is to obtain a transvaginal ultrasound to assess for an intrauterine sack. If no intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy have been identified, and hCG levels are below 2000 mIU/mL (discriminatory zone for a gestational sac to be visualized by US), serial quantitative serum hCG levels should be checked every 2 days. hCG levels in normal intrauterine pregnancy should rise ≥35% in 48 hours OR double in 72 hours. Once the levels are above the discrimination zone, transvaginal ultrasound should confirm the diagnosis of ectopic or intrauterine pregnancy. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable at presentation, FAST ultrasound and an emergency surgical consultation are appropriate.



Option Analysis

❌ Spread of pelvic inflammatory disease :
Incorrect: Tubo-ovarian abscess (TOA) is a possible complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Patients with TOA often present with acute lower abdominal pain, fever, chills, and vaginal discharge. This patient is presenting with vaginal bleeding, adnexal tenderness and positive hCG, favoring the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy. 
✅ Abnormal implantation :
 Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Premature separation of the placenta :
Incorrect: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall that occurs after 20 weeks of gestation. Typical presentation includes acute onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, and uterine tenderness. This patient is presenting with vaginal bleeding, adnexal tenderness and positive hCG before 20 weeks of gestation, favoring the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy. Also, her transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterus.
❌ Incomplete early pregnancy loss :
Incorrect: Miscarriage, or spontaneous abortion, refers to a nonviable intrauterine pregnancy up to 20 weeks gestation. Incomplete early pregnancy loss refers to retained fetal or placental tissue within the uterus after a spontaneous abortion. Bleeding and cramping are common symptoms. This patient’s transvaginal ultrasound showed no intrauterine pregnancy, which favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Obstruction of blood flow to the ovary :
Incorrect: Ovarian torsion refers to rotation of the ovary and its ligament, leading to the impedance of the blood supply. The classic presentation is acute onset of pelvic pain, nausea, and vomiting, as well as an adnexal mass. While the risk of torsion is increased in pregnant women, the transvaginal ultrasound revealed no abnormalities. Also, ovarian torsion would not present with vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman comes to the office at 15 weeks gestation due to vaginal bleeding. This morning, she woke up and noticed blood in her underwear. She has also had severe morning nausea that has been worsening, resulting in multiple episodes of vomiting throughout the day for the past week. She states it has been difficult to keep down anything she eats or drinks. She denies shortness of breath, changes in vision, or chest pain. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. On physical examination, a 19-week-size uterus and bilateral adnexal masses are palpated on bimanual examination. Laboratory tests show hCG concentrations of 110,000 mIU/mL. TSH is 0.1 μU/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with vaginal bleeding, size-date discrepancy, hyperemesis gravidarum, and new onset of hypertension before 20 weeks of gestation, raising concerns for hydatidiform mole.    

Hydatidiform mole (also known as a molar pregnancy or mole), is a premalignant disease that is caused by aberrant fertilization. A molar pregnancy can be categorized as a complete mole or partial mole, which differ by pathogenesis, gross morphology, histopathology, karyotype, and risk of malignancy. Patients often present with vaginal bleeding and hyperemesis gravidarum. Although benign, molar pregnancy increases the risk for invasive disease (e.g., choriocarcinoma, invasive mole). The risk is higher with a complete mole. Treatment is evacuation, which is both therapeutic and diagnostic. Monitoring hCG following treatment is required to detect signs of invasive disease. At the same time, contraceptives are used to prevent confusion with normal pregnancies.  



Option Analysis

❌ Choriocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Choriocarcinoma is an invasive trophoblastic neoplasia composed of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts without villi. The most common presentation is antepartum vaginal bleeding. Other signs and symptoms include respiratory symptoms due to lung metastases, neurologic symptoms due to brain metastases, and acute abdominal pain due to bleeding from intraabdominal metastases. Choriocarcinoma can develop after any type of pregnancy (e.g., molar, abortion) and rarely coexists with a normal intrauterine pregnancy. 
❌ Partial mole:
Incorrect: Partial moles occur due to fertilization of a normal ovum by two sperm and therefore are triploid (69 XXX, 69 XXY, or 69 XYY). Compared to complete mole, hCG levels are typically far lower, and uterine size is often normal. Additionally, hyperemesis gravidarum, hyperthyroidism (due to hCG), and theca lutein cysts are less common. Although further testing is required to confirm the diagnosis, this diagnosis is less likely. 
✅ Complete mole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ectopic pregnancy:
Incorrect: An ectopic pregnancy is a pregnancy that occurs outside the uterus. The vast majority of ectopic pregnancies occur within the fallopian tube. The most common presentation of ectopic pregnancy is 1st trimester vaginal bleeding and/or abdominal pain. Some may be asymptomatic. If a rupture occurs, it can result in life-threatening hemorrhage. In contrast to this patient, ectopic pregnancy presents with a lower-than-expected rise in hCG based on dates, rather than extremely high levels. 
❌ Preeclampsia:
Incorrect: Preeclampsia is defined as new-onset hypertension with either proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks gestation. This patient has a new onset of hypertension before 20 weeks of gestation and has a size-date discrepancy, favoring the diagnosis of complete mole. Preeclampsia can occur secondary to molar pregnancy, but it is not the primary diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0 comes to the clinic at 22 weeks of gestation for a follow-up appointment after she had an elevated blood pressure of 145/95 in the previous appointment. The pregnancy has been uneventful so far, and she has been taking prenatal vitamins daily. Medical history is unremarkable. She has not had any headaches, visual disturbances or urinary symptoms. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Repeated blood measurements at home are 147/92 and 146/93.  The patient’s current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 144/93 mmHg. On physical examination, cardiovascular and lung examination are unremarkable. Uterus size is consistent with 22 weeks, and fetal vital signs on nonstress test are reassuring. Urinary protein excretion on 24-hour urine is minimal, and serum creatinine concentration is 1.1 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with elevated blood pressure on 2 separate occasions, no signs of end-organ damage, and normal laboratory values after 20 weeks of gestation, favoring the diagnosis of gestational hypertension.    

Gestational hypertension is defined by the new onset of hypertension at ≥20 weeks of gestation in a patient with systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≥140 mmHg and/or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ≥90 mmHg, in the absence of proteinuria or signs of end-organ dysfunction. The measurements should be documented on at least two occasions at least four hours apart. Evaluation of gestational hypertension includes measurement of urine protein, evaluation for severe features of preeclampsia (e.g., visual disturbance, renal insufficiency), and assessment of fetal status.    

Treatment of gestational hypertension with antihypertensive medications is not indicated unless hypertension is severe (SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg), approaching the severe range, or the patient has preexisting end organ dysfunction that may be worsened by hypertension. If criteria for medical management are met, pharmacologic treatments that are safe during pregnancy include labetalol and hydralazine.  



Option Analysis

❌ Normal physiologic response to pregnancy:
Incorrect: During early pregnancy systolic and diastolic blood pressure typically falls approximately 5 to 10 mmHg below baseline due to a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. During the third trimester, blood pressure gradually increases and normalizes to normal values by term.
❌ Chronic hypertension:
Incorrect: Chronic hypertension is diagnosed if the hypertension was first detected before the 20th week of pregnancy. This patient had normal prenatal care and no preexisting conditions, making this diagnosis unlikely. If gestational blood pressure elevation persists after 12 weeks postpartum, the diagnosis is then changed to chronic hypertension. 
✅ Gestational hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Preeclampsia:
Incorrect: Preeclampsia is defined as new-onset hypertension with either proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after 20th week of gestation. This patient has no signs of end-organ dysfunction and has normal protein excretion and creatinine. Proteinuria of 300 mg/day in a 24-hour urine specimen or protein/creatinine ratio ≥ 0.3 (30 mg/mmol) defines preeclampsia.   
❌ Eclampsia:
Incorrect: Eclampsia is defined as preeclampsia plus maternal seizures, neither of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old newborn girl is evaluated in the nursery for respiratory distress. She was born at 34 weeks gestation to a 17-year-old primigravida woman who did not receive prenatal care. The patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 80/min, and blood pressure is 75/30 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. On physical examination, she appears cyanotic, and subcostal retractions and nasal flaring are noted. The nasal tip is flattened, the ears are low-set, and the chin is small and retracted backward. Appropriate treatment is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with respiratory distress and a characteristic appearance of Potter syndrome, most likely due to oligohydramnios. From the answers above, only preeclampsia, which is associated with placental insufficiency, will likely result in low amniotic fluid and fetal compression.    

Any condition that results in low amniotic fluid production or excretion can lead to fetal compression and Potter sequence. During the first trimester, amniotic fluid volume is derived from the maternal compartment, fetal secretions, and the placenta. During the second trimester, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid. Placental insufficiency (e.g., placental abruption, thrombosis, infarction, preeclampsia) will therefore result in low amniotic fluid production. The results of Potter sequence include severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia. Lung hypoplasia occurs because the fetus needs to aspirate a certain amount of amniotic fluid in order to expand and develop its lungs.  






Option Analysis

❌ Posterior urethral valve:
Incorrect: Posterior urethral valve is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in newborn males and is associated with oligohydramnios due to obstruction of urine. It is due to membrane remnants in the posterior urethra leading to urine obstruction. In utero, ultrasound may reveal bilateral hydronephrosis and thickened bladder. This infant is a female and posterior urethral valve occurs exclusively in boys. 
❌ Lung hypoplasia :
Incorrect: Any condition that results in low amniotic fluid production or excretion can lead to fetal compression and Potter sequence. The results of Potter sequence include severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia. Lung hypoplasia occurs because the fetus needs to aspirate a certain amount of amniotic fluid in order to expand and develop its lungs. Lung hypoplasia is a consequence of low amniotic fluid, not a cause. 
❌ Esophageal atresia:
Incorrect: Esophageal atresia will impair the fetus's ability to swallow amniotic fluid and will result in polyhydramnios. High amniotic fluid is not associated with Potter sequence or fetal compression, as seen in this patient. Any cause of high urine production or a decrease in fetal swallowing can lead to polyhydramnios. Potter sequence is associated with conditions that result in low amniotic fluid. 
✅ Maternal preeclampsia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Maternal diabetes mellitus :
Incorrect: A hyperglycemic state in the mother causes osmotic diuresis in the fetus, which results in polyhydramnios. Common congenital anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers include neurologic abnormalities (e.g. microcephaly), cardiovascular anomalies (e.g. transposition of the great vessels), and gastrointestinal and renal malformations (e.g. duodenal atresia, ureteral duplication). In contrast, Potter sequence is associated with oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit with active contractions every 3-5 minutes. Her previous births were via cesarean sections. One hour later, she gives birth to a healthy child. Thirty minutes after delivery, the placenta has still not been delivered. Manual extraction of the retained placenta is performed and leads to profuse bleeding. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, the uterus is firm and nontender. Hemoglobin is 9 g/dL and platelet count is 220,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient’s bleeding?

choices.text: Profound activation of the coagulation cascade
Placental implantation near the cervical os
Abnormal trophoblast invasion into the uterine wall
Abnormal implantation of the fetal vessels

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postpartum hemorrhage and hypotension after manual extraction of the placenta, favoring the diagnosis of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS).  

PAS refers to an abnormal trophoblastic invasion into the myometrium of the uterine wall due to placental implantation at an area of faulty decidualization. This abnormal implantation is typically caused by pre-existing damage to the uterine wall, such as prior cesarean section. PAS includes placenta accreta (attaches to the myometrium rather than decidua), increta (penetrates the myometrium), and percreta (through the myometrium to the uterine serosa/adjacent organs). Risk factors include prior cesarean section, uterine procedures, maternal age > 35 years, multiparity, history of pelvic irradiation, and postpartum endometritis. PAS often present with profuse, life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs during manual placental separation. Management typically includes supportive care, and in most cases, hysterectomy is indicated.



Option Analysis

❌ Profound activation of the coagulation cascade :
Incorrect: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a systemic condition in which coagulation and fibrinolysis are abnormally activated, leading to thrombosis and hemorrhage. This complication can occur during postpartum hemorrhage; however, DIC leads to prolonged aPTT and PTT, elevation of fibrin degradation products and D-dimer, and consumption of platelets. This patient has a normal platelet count. Also, manifestations of DIC include petechiae, as well as blood oozing from wound sites (e.g. intravenous lines) and mucosal surfaces. 
❌ Placental implantation near the cervical os :
Incorrect: Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implementation over or in proximity to the cervical os. Placenta previa should be suspected in any pregnant woman who presents with painless vaginal bleeding after 20 weeks gestation. Diagnosis is made via ultrasound, and a cesarean section is usually indicated. This patient's presentation and ultrasound findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Abnormal trophoblast invasion into the uterine wall  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Premature placental separation :
Incorrect: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall that occurs after 20 weeks gestation. Typical presentation includes acute onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, and uterine tenderness. However, placental abruption occurs before delivery, not after.   
❌ Abnormal implantation of the fetal vessels:
Incorrect: Vasa previa is a condition in which the fetal blood vessels that implant into the placenta cover the internal os of the uterus. Clinical presentation includes a classic triad of rupture of membranes, painless vaginal bleeding, followed by fetal bradycardia. This patient presents with postpartum hemorrhage after manual extraction of the placenta, favoring another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 3, comes to the labor and delivery unit at the 38 weeks gestation due to vaginal bleeding. She did not receive any prenatal care during this pregnancy. The patient’s first 2 children were born through normal vaginal delivery, while her last child was delivered through C-section due to second stage arrest. She is in good health and takes no medications other than prenatal vitamins. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Fetal heart rate is 85/min and fetal heart rate tracing shows a sinusoidal pattern. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. The uterus is non-tender on palpation. Speculum examination reveals ruptured membranes, closed cervix, and profuse bleeding from the cervical os. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who did not receive prenatal care, is presenting with painless vaginal bleeding upon rupture of the membranes, which is accompanied by fetal heart rate tracing showing a sinusoidal pattern and bradycardia; she most likely suffered from ruptured vasa previa.    

Vasa previa is a condition in which the fetal blood vessels are found in the membranes that cover the internal cervical os. Patients often present with painless vaginal bleeding upon rupture of membranes, accompanied by fetal heart rate abnormalities such as bradycardia or sinusoidal pattern. Fetal exsanguination can occur within minutes. The exact pathogenesis of vasa previa is unknown. Risk factors for developing vasa previa include velamentous cord insertion, umbilical cord insertion in the lower uterus, placenta previa or low-lying placenta, succenturiate placental lobe or bilobed placenta, in vitro fertilization, and multiple gestations. Diagnosis of vasa previa is made by demonstrating the fetal vessels passing across the internal cervical os by transvaginal ultrasound examination with color Doppler. Delivery is usually made via planned cesarean delivery at 34 to 35 weeks of gestation or by emergency cesarean delivery if a rupture occurred. Vasa previa is often associated with velamentous umbilical cord insertion, in which the umbilical inserts to the chorioamniotic membranes instead of the placenta and therefore is not protected by Wharton's jelly.  



Option Analysis

❌ Placenta accreta:
Incorrect: Placenta accreta refers to a placenta that attaches to the myometrium without penetrating it. Placenta accreta presents as a life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs after delivery when manual placental separation is attempted. This patient has not yet delivered, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Placental abruption :
Incorrect: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall that occurs after 20 weeks gestation. Typical presentation includes acute onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, and uterine tenderness. 
✅ Vasa previa :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ​Placenta previa :
Incorrect: Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implementation over or in proximity to the cervical os. Placenta previa should be suspected in any pregnant woman who presents with painless vaginal bleeding after 20 weeks gestation. Diagnosis is made via ultrasound, and a cesarean section is usually indicated. Although this patient has risk factors for placenta previa (e.g., multiparity, prior C-section), the fetal heart rate pattern and low heart rate suggest that the bleeding occurred from the fetal side (vasa previa). Since placenta previa involves maternal vessels, it would more likely result in maternal instability, which is not seen in this patient. 
❌ Uterine rupture:
Incorrect: Uterine rupture typically presents with severe abdominal and uterine pain with/without hemodynamic changes, vaginal bleeding, and fetal heart rate changes (most commonly bradycardia). However, loss of fetal station (station refers to the stage of the presenting fetal part; therefore, loss of station means regression of the fetus back into the uterus), cessation of contractions, and changes in uterine contour are also expected. Risk factors are previous classical uterine incision and myomectomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a progressive cough accompanied by mild hemoptysis. During the past 2 weeks, she has been experiencing non-productive cough, pelvic pressure, and mild vaginal bleeding. Six weeks ago, the patient had an abortion at 15 weeks gestation, and since then, her menstrual period had not yet returned. She is in good health, and she does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. She is sexually active with her male partner and currently does not use contraception. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the uterus is soft and mildly enlarged. Vaginal examination shows minimal blood at the vaginal vault. The cervix is closed, non-erythematous. An x-ray of the chest is obtained and shows multiple, rounded nodules of variable size scattered throughout the lungs. Which of the following findings is most specific for this patient’s conditions?

choices.text: Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies on immunofluorescence
Positive acid-fast bacilli on sputum analysis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with vaginal bleeding, enlarged uterus, cough, and hemoptysis following a recent abortion. Along with the x-ray findings showing a cannonball pattern (lung metastases), the most likely diagnosis is choriocarcinoma. It is associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).    

Choriocarcinoma is a type of invasive gestational trophoblastic neoplasia characterized by abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic tissue. Choriocarcinoma is highly vascular and composed of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts without villi. Choriocarcinoma can follow any type of pregnancy but more commonly occurs after molar pregnancy. Patients often present with vaginal bleeding or amenorrhea, pelvic pain or pressure, and an enlarged soft uterus. Dyspnea, chest pain, cough, or hemoptysis may occur from lung metastases, as seen in this patient. Cannonball appearance on chest x-ray is characteristic. Metastases to the liver and central nervous system may also occur; metastatic disease to the brain typically presents with headaches, dizziness, nausea, slurred speech or visual disturbances. On ultrasound, choriocarcinoma appears as a heterogeneous mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. Color doppler will show a markedly hypervascular lesion.    

Choriocarcinoma is uniquely sensitive to chemotherapy, and therefore, management involves treatment with chemotherapeutic agents, namely, methotrexate. Women with choriocarcinoma should be monitored with serial measurements of serum hCG at the start of treatment and then at weekly intervals during therapy. After remission is achieved, serum hCG should be measured monthly until monitoring has shown one year of normal hCG levels.  

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
Pulmonary metastases - “cannonball” appearance on chest x-ray

Option Analysis

❌ Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies on immunofluorescence :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Goodpasture disease, a small vessel vasculitis characterized by antibodies directed against the glomerular basement membrane and alveolar basement membrane, resulting in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and/or alveolar hemorrhage. The absence of renal symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, it would not explain the patient's vaginal bleeding. 
❌ Anti-proteinase 3 antibodies on immunofluorescence :
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) is a type of granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis that is associated with antinuclear antibodies and specifically with anti-proteinase 3 antibodies. Patients typically present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), signs of systemic inflammation (e.g., elevated ESR and CRP), asthma, sinusitis, palpable purpura, renal involvement, and neurologic deficits. The absence of atopic history or other symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Positive acid-fast bacilli on sputum analysis :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) infection. While TB infection can present with hemoptysis, the absence of fever and the presence of vaginal bleeding is not consistent with the diagnosis. Moreover, an x-ray of active tuberculosis will likely show an upper lobe lesion rather than multiple scattered nodules. 
✅ Elevated serum hCG levels :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated d-dimer:
Incorrect: D-dimer is not specific and is often elevated in many conditions including pulmonary embolism (PE) and malignancy. While PE can present with cough and hemoptysis, other findings such as tachycardia, dyspnea, and mild fever are also expected. PE would not explain the patient’s x-ray and vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the labor and delivery triage at 24 weeks gestation due to severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and contractions. Pregnancy has been uneventful other than hypertension of 149/90 during her last visit. She has been compliant with prenatal care and took prenatal vitamins throughout the pregnancy. Medical history is significant for smoking 1 pack per day for 10 years which she reduced during pregnancy to half a pack per day. She is otherwise healthy and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears in acute distress due to pain. Pelvic examination shows a rigid and tender uterus. High-frequency and low-amplitude uterine contractions are noted. There is minimal bleeding present in the vaginal vault. There is no change in fetal station. The fetal heart rate is 160 bpm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This primigravida woman is presenting with sudden onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, high-frequency/low-amplitude uterine contractions, and signs of fetal distress (tachycardia), favoring the diagnosis of abruptio placenta.    

Abruptio placenta (placental abruption) is the premature separation of all or a part of the placenta from the uterine wall, resulting in hemorrhage. Placental abruption typically occurs after 20 weeks gestation. The clinical findings are vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, high-frequency/low-amplitude uterine contractions, uterine tenderness, and uterine rigidity. The uterine tachysystole occurs due to blood penetrating the myometrial wall, resulting in irritation and subsequent contractions and rigidity. The vaginal bleeding may be concealed and accumulate between the fetal membranes and decidua. Placental abruption is associated with significant maternal morbidity and neonatal morbidity and mortality. Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation and imaging; typically an ultrasound will show a retroplacental collection of blood. Management depends on the maternal and fetal stability and includes supportive care with/or without emergent cesarean section. Risk factors for the development of placental abruption include maternal hypertension, prior placental abruption, cocaine use, smoking, and trauma.  



Option Analysis

❌ Uterine rupture :
Incorrect: Uterine rupture also presents with abdominal pain with/without hemodynamic changes, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and fetal heart rate changes (most commonly bradycardia). However, loss of fetal station (station refers to the stage of the presenting fetal part; therefore, loss of station means regression of the fetus back into the uterus because of the rupture), cessation of contractions (as opposed to this patient’s high-frequency/low-amplitude contractions), and changes in uterine contour are also expected. Risk factors are previous classical uterine incision and myomectomy.
✅ Placenta abruption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Placenta previa:
Incorrect: Placenta previa refers to placental tissue implantation over the internal cervical os that covers all or part of the cervix. The classic presentation is painless late-pregnancy vaginal bleeding. Significant risk factors include previous cesarean deliveries, previous uterine surgery, multiple gestations, and previous placenta previa. The presence of pain and a tender uterus in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Chorioamnionitis :
Incorrect: Chorioamnionitis refers to an acute inflammation of the amniotic membranes and chorion. Chorioamnionitis is typically seen in women with prelabor rupture of membranes (which allows for bacterial migration and colonization) but can also occur with intact membranes. Symptoms include fever, maternal and fetal tachycardia, uterine tenderness, bacteremia, and purulent or malodorous amniotic fluid. Maternal fever is required for diagnosis and is not seen in this patient. 
❌ Placenta accreta:
Incorrect: Placenta accreta refers to a placenta that attaches to the myometrium without penetrating it. Placenta accreta presents as a life-threatening hemorrhage that occurs after delivery when manual placental separation is attempted. This patient has not yet delivered, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman is evaluated by an obstetrician after delivering a healthy baby 24 hours ago. The delivery was complicated by protraction in the first labor stage and augmented by an infusion bolus of oxytocin. After delivery, she suffered from excessive postpartum bleeding, which was successfully managed with oxytocin infusion and bimanual uterine massage. Which of the following side effects might develop as a result of oxytocin administration?
questions.solution:
This patient was administered oxytocin for labor induction and to treat her postpartum hemorrhage–increasing the risk of developing associated side effects. One known side effect is the development of hyponatremia.

Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced by the hypothalamus and stored and released in the posterior pituitary. It stimulates uterine contraction by binding to Gq protein-coupled receptors. Once activated, these receptors activate another molecule called phospholipase C. Phospholipase C cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4,5 bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate. Finally, inositol triphosphate promotes the opening of calcium channels in the endoplasmic reticulum, enhancing calcium release into the cytoplasm, which mediates the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Exogenous oxytocin administration is indicated for both ante- and postpartum conditions. In the antepartum period, oxytocin is administered to strengthen uterine contractions to induce or facilitate labor. Oxytocin is also administered to treat postpartum hemorrhage as it mediates the contraction of the uterus and subsequent closure of uterine vasculature.

Side effects of oxytocin include vasodilation, which may result in hypotension and tachycardia. In addition, patients may develop water retention and hyponatremia. This occurs secondary to the ability of oxytocin to act on antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the renal tubules, promoting free water retention. Finally, oxytocin can lead to tachysystole (5 or more contractions in 10 minutes over a 30-minute duration).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hyponatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: When oxytocin is administered excessively or for prolonged periods, it acts similarly to antidiuretic hormone, promoting free water reabsorption and hyponatremia.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is not a side effect of oxytocin.  
❌ Venous thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid (TXA) is sometimes used in patients with severe postpartum hemorrhage. TXA is an antifibrinolytic medication that prevents blood clots from breaking down. VTE is not a known side effect of oxytocin administration.  
❌ Bronchoconstriction:
Incorrect: Bronchoconstriction is a known side effect of prostaglandins and prostaglandin analogs (carboprost).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 31 weeks gestation, gravida 1 para 0, is admitted to the delivery unit due to preterm labor. The patient presented with regular uterus contractions and evidence of cervical dilation. Her pregnancy was uneventful, and she has regularly followed up with her prenatal care. The physician starts the patient on indomethacin and betamethasone. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of indomethacin?

choices.text: Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium
Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus

questions.solution:
This patient presented in preterm labor and was administered indomethacin to delay labor and allow for timely administration of glucocorticoids.

Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX), which are responsible for the synthesis of prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are necessary for uterine contraction.

Indomethacin can be used as a tocolytic only if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks. After 32 weeks, prostaglandins are contraindicated, as they may lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus. In addition, indomethacin inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins in other organs like the stomach, increasing the risk of gastritis and gastric bleeding. Indomethacin can also induce placental dysfunction (due to vasoconstriction).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks oxytocin receptors:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor that blocks the synthesis of prostaglandins. It does not affect oxytocin receptors.  
❌ Increase the prostaglandin synthesis:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor resulting in decreased prostaglandins synthesis.  
❌ Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium:
Incorrect: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium, resulting in decreased intracellular calcium and, therefore, inhibition of the uterine contractions.  
❌ Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is another tocolytic that stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus. Indomethacin does not exert any effects on this receptor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old gravida 2 para 1 woman at 34 weeks gestation comes to her obstetrician for follow-up. She was diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus, which is well-controlled with diet modification and metformin. Her past medical history includes asthma, but she does not take any medications for asthma control. Her previous delivery occurred via spontaneous vaginal delivery.  The patient was noted to have placenta previa on ultrasonography at the 28th week of gestation. Repeat ultrasound reveals the placenta in a normal anatomic location and is no longer covering the cervical os. The fetus is positioned in a transverse lie. Which of the following is a contraindication to oxytocin administration for labor induction?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced by the posterior pituitary that stimulates uterine contractions. Exogenous oxytocin administration is indicated to initiate or facilitate vaginal delivery and treat postpartum hemorrhage.

Oxytocin administration is contraindicated in a few settings. Patients with hypersensitivity to oxytocin cannot receive this medication. In addition, oxytocin is contraindicated in any patient with a contraindication to vaginal delivery. This includes patients with unfavorable fetal position or presentation (e.g. transverse lie or cord presentation), active genital herpes, invasive cervical carcinoma, placenta previa, vasa previa, or cord prolapse.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transverse lie:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Placenta previa:
Incorrect: Although this patient had placenta previa, the placenta has now ascended to its normal anatomic location. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Gestational diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Gestational diabetes mellitus is neither a contraindication for vaginal delivery nor oxytocin induction of labor. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Asthma is not a contraindication to oxytocin administration. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Patient age:
Incorrect: Patient age is not a contraindication for oxytocin administration. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman develops severe vaginal bleeding after delivery. The patient had gestational diabetes mellitus during pregnancy and delivered a 9 lb 3 oz infant. Uterine massage is applied, and oxytocin is administered without hemorrhage control. Three units of packed red blood cells are administered, and she is also provided with dinoprostone. Which of the following side effects are most commonly associated with dinoprostone?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed postpartum hemorrhage likely due to uterine atony. She was administered dinoprostone, a prostaglandin analog.

Prostaglandin analogs like misoprostol (PGE2) and dinoprostone (PGE1) are effective in stimulating uterine contractions for the management of postpartum hemorrhage and in facilitating labor or inducing abortion. They act by stimulating receptors on the uterine smooth muscle. These receptors are coupled with Gq, and once stimulated, they induce the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing muscle contraction.

Side effects of prostaglandin analogs include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. They can also cause uterine pain and hyperstimulation. Because dinoprostone can stimulate prostaglandin receptors on the smooth muscle of the bronchioles, it can also cause bronchoconstriction and must be avoided in patients with underlying asthma.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Bronchoconstriction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Oxytocin can cause hyponatremia if administered excessively or for prolonged periods due to its structural similarity to antidiuretic hormone. However, hyponatremia is not a known side effect of dinoprostone.  
❌ Gastric ulcers:
Incorrect: Gastric ulcers can develop as a side effect of prostaglandin inhibitors. However, dinoprostone is a prostaglandin analog and is protective against gastric ulcers.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is a known side effect of ergonovine; it is not associated with dinoprostone use.  
❌ Venous thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic drug that can be used to treat postpartum hemorrhage and can cause venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 24-year-old gravida 2 para 1 woman comes to the obstetrician for evaluation of painful uterine contractions. The patient is in the 32<sup>nd</sup> week of gestation. She describes her contractions as regular and increasing in frequency. The patient has a history of preterm delivery in her previous pregnancy. She did not have any complications during this pregnancy. Examination reveals cervical dilation. The physician decides to administer terbutaline. Which of the following is a possible side effect of terbutaline?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with preterm labor, defined as regular uterine contractions before 37 weeks of gestation. Preterm labor carries significant morbidity and mortality to neonates, especially before the 34th week of gestation. Patients with onset of labor before 34 weeks of gestation are administered tocolytics to delay labor and provide time for corticosteroid administration to stimulate fetal lung maturation.

Tocolytics are a group of medications that delay the onset of labor in patients presenting with preterm labor. Specifically, Terbutaline is a beta-agonist that is used for tocolysis. Beta-2 receptors are found in the walls of the uterine smooth muscles. These are Gs protein-coupled receptors and, once activated, induce cyclic AMP formation (cAMP) by activating adenylyl cyclase. Once cAMP is formed, it phosphorylates protein kinase A and deactivates myosin light-chain kinase, inhibiting smooth muscle contraction.

Terbutaline is a selective Beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonist used to delay labor by inhibiting uterine contractions. It is used for short-term tocolysis and uterine tachysystole.

Adverse effects of terbutaline occur secondary to its effects on beta-receptors. In the mother, terbutaline can cause tachycardia, arrhythmias, myocardial ischemia, hypotension, and pulmonary edema. Finally, terbutaline can lead to hyperglycemia and is contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperglycemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia, is a known side-effect of terbutaline, as it is a beta-agonist.  
❌ Premature closure of ductus arteriosus:
Incorrect: Closure of ductus arteriosus is a known effect of indomethacin due to inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis, but terbutaline does not affect prostaglandins.  
❌ Gastritis:
Incorrect: Gastritis is a known complication of indomethacin use but is not associated with terbutaline.  
❌ Bradycardia:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is a beta-agonist, leading to tachycardia and tachyarrhythmias, not bradycardia.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 30 weeks gestational age, comes to her primary care physician to evaluate joint pain and fatigue. The patient reports that her symptoms began two weeks ago. Her current pregnancy is notable for gestational hypertension, for which she is taking methyldopa, and an episode of cystitis at 20 weeks, which was successfully treated with antibiotics. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Physical examination reveals a facial rash affecting the cheeks and nasal bridge. Bilateral lungs are clear to auscultation, and there is no abdominal tenderness. Uterine fundal height is consistent with gestational age. The bilateral wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints are noted with stiffness and pain with passive movement. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?  

Laboratory Value  
Result
Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL  
Hematocrit
37.5%
Leukocyte
3,900/mm3   
Platelet
200,000
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms consistent with drug-induced lupus (e.g., malar rash, arthralgia, leukopenia). Given her history of gestational hypertension, she was started on methyldopa, which is one of the four medications commonly used to treat hypertension in pregnancy (hydralazine, methyldopa, labetalol, nifedipine). Methyldopa is associated with drug-induced lupus.

Methyldopa works via a complex mechanism of action. First, methyldopa is converted into methyldopamine by the enzyme DOPA decarboxylase. Second, it moves into synaptic vesicles, where methyldopamine is converted to methylnorepinephrine. Third, methylnorepinephrine accumulates within the vesicles and pushes norepinephrine into the cytoplasm. Monoamine oxidases degrade the norepinephrine, and over time, the presynaptic norepinephrine stores become depleted. Lastly, when a signal comes, methylnorepinephrine is released into the synapse. It cannot activate adrenergic receptors in the postsynaptic neuron but can act on α2-receptors, further decreasing norepinephrine release.

However, methyldopa is associated with many side effects. These range from mild ones, such as drowsiness, fatigue, and nausea/gastric upset, to severe ones, such as liver toxicity, drug-induced lupus, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Non-selective blockade of α-adrenergic receptors:
Incorrect: Phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine are nonselective alpha-blockers that reduce both α1 and α2 activity. However, they are not typically used to treat gestational hypertension and are not associated with drug-induced lupus, which can present with a malar rash, arthralgia, and leukopenia.  
❌ Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with drug-induced lupus. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can be administered for 3-days to treat cystitis during pregnancy. This treatment duration would likely be too short of triggering drug-induced lupus. Moreover, the symptoms would have likely resolved after the medication was discontinued.  
❌ Inhibition of prokaryotic DNA topoisomerase:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones are used to treat urinary tract infections in the general population but not in pregnant women. This is because fluoroquinolones can cause cartilage damage in the developing fetus.
✅ Reduction of synaptic norepinephrine stores:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blockade of L-type calcium channels:
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers, such as nifedipine, work via this mechanism of action. Nifedipine is used to treat gestational hypertension. However, it would not cause drug-induced lupus as a side effect.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman is evaluated for acute vaginal bleeding following vaginal delivery 2 hours ago at 37 weeks of gestation. The pregnancy was uneventful. The patient has chronic hypertension and was treated with nifedipine throughout pregnancy. Uterine massage is initiated, and 1 unit of packed red blood cells is administered. The physician decides to administer uterotonic agents. Which of the following uterotonic agents must be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Postpartum hemorrhage is one of the most common obstetric complications associated with significant morbidity and mortality. It is defined as acute blood loss of 500 ml after vaginal delivery (or 1L after cesarean section).

Ergonovine is a uterotonic agent used to manage postpartum hemorrhage (unlike oxytocin, ergonovine cannot be used for stimulating labor). Although the mechanism of action of ergonovine is poorly understood, it is thought to stimulate contractions of uterine smooth muscles and vascular smooth muscles.

Because of its vasoconstrictive properties, ergonovine is associated with hypertension and is, therefore, contraindicated in patients with underlying hypertension. It can also induce vasospasm of coronary arteries, leading to angina. Finally, ergonovine can lead to other side effects like headache, nausea, and vomiting.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ergonovine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oxytocin:
Incorrect: This patient can take oxytocin as there are no contraindications for its use in this patient.  
❌ Carboprost:
Incorrect: Carboprost is a synthetic prostaglandin analog that can be used to stimulate uterine contractions. Its use is contraindicated in patients with asthma, as it induces bronchospasm.  
❌ Tranexamic acid:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic medication used as a second-line agent to treat postpartum hemorrhage. It has no absolute contraindications but must be used cautiously in patients with a prior history of venous hypercoagulability due to the increased risk of venous thromboembolism.  
❌ Misoprostol:
Incorrect: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E2 analog and is used in the management of postpartum hemorrhage. It has no absolute contraindications and can be used in this patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician for a routine follow-up six weeks after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient has no active complaints at this visit but would like to discuss contraception. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After discussing the risks and benefits of multiple contraceptive options, the patient elects to start depot medroxyprogesterone. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Depot medroxyprogesterone is an injectable, progestin-only contraceptive that provides highly effective, reversible contraception for three months. It causes menstrual irregularities such as prolonged bleeding or spotting, especially during the first six months of use. Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestogen called progestin.  Progestins can be divided into two groups: the progesterone derivatives and the testosterone derivatives.

Progestins suppress ovulation by inhibiting the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone from the hypothalamus, induce atrophic changes in the endometrium, and thicken the cervical mucus. While they can stabilize the endometrium, they can’t support pregnancy effectively as endogenous progesterone does.

Common indications include:
 
  • Contraception, either alone or in combination with an estrogen 
  • Used in combination with estrogen in hormone replacement therapy after menopause in women with an intact uterus to prevent endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer 
  • Diagnosis and treatment of various gynecological conditions such as secondary amenorrhea, abnormal uterine bleeding, and endometriosis. 
Side effects associated with progestins include fatigue, mood changes, menstrual irregularities, edema, vaginal dryness or atrophy, headaches, nausea, breast tenderness, and decreased libido. Progestins with androgenic activity can also cause acne, hirsutism, seborrhea, voice deepening, changes in liver protein production, and weight gain.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Menstrual irregularities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type 2 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Although estrogen oral contraceptive pills have shown to increase the risk of glucose intolerance, progestins have not been linked to the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Breast cancer:
Incorrect: The data for progestin-only contraceptives are inadequate to make a definitive conclusion regarding the risk of breast cancer.  
❌ Endometrial hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Progestins reverse endometrial hyperplasia via activation of progesterone receptors, which results in stromal decidualization and subsequent thinning of the endometrium. It is used to prevent endometrial hyperplasia and cancer by mitigating the effect of estrogen on the endometrium.  
❌ Migraine headaches:
Incorrect: Estrogen therapy often improves both symptoms for women with hot flashes and estrogen-associated migraines (which typically worsen during perimenopause). Migraine headaches (with or without aura) are not a complication of progestin therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a red rash over her right breast for the past three months. The rash is itchy and feels rough to the touch. The patient has tried applying emollients without relief. Her last menstrual period was three years ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus. Family history is significant for ovarian cancer in the patient’s grandmother at age 40. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows redness and swelling of the right breast without palpable masses. The overlying skin appears indurated and retracted. The right nipple appears normal, and the left breast examination is unremarkable. This patient’s physical examination findings are most likely due to the involvement of which of the following breast structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with a peau d’orange rash due to the involvement of axillary lymph nodes.  This finding is highly associated with inflammatory breast cancer. Axillary lymph nodes serve as the most common site of breast cancer metastasis, and peau d'orange manifests secondary to cutaneous lymphatic edema and obstruction. Clinically, this rash is characterized by a thickened, leather-like appearance of the skin. Prominent “puffy” skin between dimpled pores gives the overlying skin the appearance of an orange peel (peau d’orange sign).  

Breast cancer often presents as a palpable breast mass that is hard, immobile, and with irregular borders. It is most commonly found in the upper outer quadrants with associated skin dimpling. Cancerous invasion of the glandular tissue and fibrosis may pull on the breast's suspensory ligaments, resulting in retraction of the nipple.  

When breast cancer invades the retro mammary space or the pectoral fascia, or when it metastasizes to the interpectoral nodes, the breast elevates when the muscle contracts. This finding usually signals advanced cancer. Furthermore, local cancerous invasion of the pectoral fascia and pectoralis major may result in deep fixation of the breast tissue.



Nipple retraction
Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Retromammary space:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can spread contiguously, including the retro mammary space or the pectoral fascia. Peau d’orange appearance in this patient suggests axillary lymph node invasion. When breast cancer metastasizes to the interpectoral nodes, the breast elevates when the pectoral muscle contracts.  
✅ Axillary lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Nipple  :
Incorrect: Involvement of the nipple occurs in patients with Paget disease of the breast, characterized by eczematous exudate over the nipple and areola.  
❌ Suspensory ligament:
Incorrect: Dimpling of the skin can result from the invasion of glandular tissue and fibrosis, which may place tension on the suspensory ligaments of the breast. This most commonly presents with retraction of the nipple and distortion of the breast contour.  
❌ Lactiferous duct:
Incorrect: The lactiferous ducts connect the nipple to the mammary lobules for lactation. Spread of ductal carcinoma through the ductal system may present with nipple discharge.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with Klinefelter syndrome comes to the office to evaluate a painless left breast mass he first noticed while bathing last night. The mass is not associated with pain, discharge, or erythema. The patient feels well and does not have any chronic medical conditions. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination 4 cm subareolar left breast mass and enlarged left axillary lymph nodes. Mammography demonstrates irregular microcalcifications. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is performed and is suggestive of infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Which of the following best differentiates breast cancer in men and women?

choices.text: Breast cancer typically presents at an earlier age in men.
Breast cancer typically presents in more advanced stages in men.
Lobular histology is less common in women.
Inherited breast cancers due to BRCA1 mutations present more commonly in men.
There are higher rates of hormone receptor expression in women.

questions.solution:
Breast cancer primarily affects biological females and is the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in women in the United States; however, up to 1.5% of cases occur in biological males. Breast cancer in males differs from breast cancer in females in the following aspects:  

  • Presents in more advanced stages with retro areolar location and chest wall involvement 
  • Higher rates of hormone receptor expression 
  • BRCA2 > BRCA1  
  • Lobular histology is less common

Unfortunately, breast cancer in men frequently goes undetected until metastatic symptoms present.

In males, breast cancer usually metastasizes to the axillary lymph nodes in addition to the bone, pleura, lung, liver, and skin. Breast cancer infiltrates the pectoral fascia, pectoralis major muscle, and apical lymph nodes in the axilla. 

Option Analysis

❌ Breast cancer typically presents at an earlier age in men.:
Incorrect: As with women, the incidence of breast cancer in men rises with age. Men tend to be 5 to 10 years older than women at the diagnosis.  
✅ Breast cancer typically presents in more advanced stages in men.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lobular histology is less common in women.  :
Incorrect: Most women's histologic subtypes of breast cancer are also present in men. Lobular carcinomas are rare in men (not women).  
❌ Inherited breast cancers due to BRCA1 mutations present more commonly in men.:
Incorrect: Most inherited breast cancers in women are due to BRCA1 mutations, which rarely present in men.  
❌ There are higher rates of hormone receptor expression in women.:
Incorrect: This is true for breast cancer in men, not women. Excessive estrogen stimulation may occur due to hormonal therapies (e.g., estrogen-containing compounds or testosterone), hepatic dysfunction, obesity, thyroid disease, or an inherited condition, such as Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a left breast mass. She has no associated symptoms. Her last menstrual period was one year ago, and she does not have any significant medical history. Family history is essential for breast cancer in the patient’s mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the breast shows a 2-cm firm, irregular round mass over the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Mammography demonstrates a spiculated soft tissue mass with microcalcifications. If left untreated, this patient’s tumor is most likely to spread to the following locations first?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer usually spreads via lymphatic vessels, especially to the axillary lymph nodes (the most common site of metastasis). This patient presents with an irregular, palpable breast mass. This, in combination with her mammographic findings, is concerning for underlying breast cancer.
