Most lymph, especially from the superolateral quadrant and center of the breast, drains into the axillary lymph nodes, emptying into the subclavian lymphatic trunk. On the right, the lymphatic trunk drains into the venous system via the right lymphatic duct, whereas lymph from the left breast returns to the venous system via the thoracic duct.  

Breast cancer may spread to the vertebral bodies and central nervous system. Breast cancer cells can also spread from the breast via the venous system. The posterior intercostal veins drain into the azygos/hemi-azygos system of veins, which subsequently communicate with the internal vertebral venous plexus surrounding the spinal cord.



Option Analysis

❌ Azygos/Hemi-azygos veins:
Incorrect: Cancerous cells can spread from the breast through venous routes. For example, the posterior intercostal veins drain into the azygos system of veins; however, the axillary lymph nodes are the most common site of metastasis for breast cancer cells.  
✅ Axillary lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pectoral fascia:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can invade the pectoral fascia; however, axillary lymph nodes remain the most common spread site for metastatic breast cancer.  
❌ Retromammary space:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can invade the retro mammary space; however, axillary lymph nodes remain the most common spread site for metastatic breast cancer.  
❌ Brain:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can spread from the breast via the azygos/hemi-azygos system of veins to the brain. Axillary lymph nodes remain the most common initial site of metastasis for breast cancer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office with his wife for evaluation of infertility. They have been married for two years and have attempted to conceive without success. The patient’s wife has a child from her previous marriage. The patient reports decreased libido but finds it challenging to maintain an erection. Past medical history is unremarkable. He takes no medications besides a multivitamin daily. Family history is noncontributory. The patient’s height is 185cm (6ft 1inch), and weight is 66 kg (145.5 lb). Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows sparse facial and body hair and enlarged breasts. Olfactory sensation and visual field testing are within normal limits. Genital examination shows normal male external morphology and firm testes with a volume of 6 ml (normal 18-25 mL). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s breast enlargement?
questions.solution:
This patient’s infertility associated with tall stature, decreased virilization, small testes, and gynecomastia is consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, the most common cause of hypogonadism.  

Gynecomastia refers to a benign proliferation of the breast tissue in biological males, and it is typically caused by an imbalance between estrogenic and androgenic hormones. It differs from the proliferation of breast tissue in females in that there is no terminal alveolar development in response to progesterone.  

Gynecomastia is age-dependent, and it most frequently affects males progressing through puberty. Adolescents with pubertal gynecomastia usually complain of a mass or lump behind the nipple.    

Gynecomastia affects older males less frequently. This population can be caused by liver cirrhosis or testicular cancer, medications like spironolactone, cimetidine, ketoconazole,  and conditions such as Klinefelter syndrome.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Medication adverse effect:
Incorrect: Medications that inhibit testosterone synthesis and action (e.g. ketoconazole), enhance endogenous estrogen production (e.g. clomiphene), or have estrogen-like activity (e.g. oral contraceptive pills) can result in gynecomastia.
❌ Physiological enlargement  :
Incorrect: Pubertal gynecomastia refers to physiological enlargement of the glandular breast tissue that occurs in some boys during puberty. This patient’s presentation suggests an alternative explanation.  
✅ Hypogonadism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Testicular cancer  :
Incorrect: Hormone secreting testicular cancer (e.g. Leydig or Sertoli cell tumors) can cause gynecomastia and present with a palpable testicular mass on physical examination (in contrast to this patient’s firm small testes).  
❌ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia  :
Incorrect: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can present with gynecomastia due to increased production of estrogen precursors. It is characterized by increased virilization (e.g. increased body hair), unlike this patient with sparse body hair.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the office following abnormal results found on screening mammography. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin. She is otherwise healthy. She does not smoke or use excessive alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a solid non-tender mass is palpated in the upper right quadrant of the right breast. A non-tender, fixed axillary lymph node is also palpated. The nipple and areola appear normal. A core needle biopsy reveals the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s lesion most likely arises from which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
This patient had an abnormal mammogram screening, followed by a core-needle biopsy that is consistent with the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, the most common type of breast cancer. Breast cancers are classified according to their morphology, as well as whether they have penetrated the basement membrane. The most common types of breast cancer includes invasive ductal carcinoma (70%) and invasive lobular carcinoma (10% to 15%). The term lobular or ductal is a bit of a misnomer, as both arise from the terminal duct lobular unit. Ductal carcinoma spreads to the ducts, while lobular carcinoma spreads to the lobules.  





Option Analysis

❌ Breast stroma:
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from the breast stroma (interlobular tissue) include fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumor. However, this patient’s presentation implies invasive disease (palpable, fixed lymph node), in addition to the histological picture, which is consistent with invasive ductal carcinoma.   
❌ Lactiferous duct:
Incorrect: Paget's disease of the breast is an extension of underlying ductal carcinoma in situ/invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts and the contiguous skin of the nipple. Patients typically present with eczematous patches over the nipple. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple. Other lesions that may arise from the ducts include intraductal papilloma, abscess, or mastitis. This patient’s presentation and histology results favor another diagnosis.    
❌ Lactiferous sinus:
Incorrect: The sinuses are an extension of the lactiferous duct and are the location in which milk accumulates. Clogged ducts, galactoceles, intraductal papillomas, abscesses and mastitis may arise from this area.  
✅ Terminal duct lobular unit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lobules :
Incorrect: There are no breast lesions that arise from the lobules themselves. Lobular carcinoma in situ or invasive lobular carcinoma both arise from the terminal duct lobular unit and spread to the lobules.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a left breast mass. She first noticed it a few months ago, and since then, it has progressively grown in size. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2, for which she takes metformin. She does not smoke, drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a smooth, well-defined, firm and mobile mass is noted in the left breast. There is no associated pain, and the rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below:  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s lesion most likely arises from which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a smooth, well-defined, firm and mobile mass which requires further investigation. Her biopsy results show connective tissue and cysts with “leaf-like” lobulations, confirming the diagnosis of phyllodes tumor.   

Breast tissue is composed of mammary gland tissue, fibrous and fatty tissue, blood and lymph vessels, and nerves. The functional unit of the breast is the lobule, a glandular tissue that is lined with alveolar cells that secrete milk surrounded by myoepithelial cells that propagates it. The lobules are supported by a specialized intralobular stroma. The rest of the breast consists of the interlobular stroma, which is made of adipose and connective tissue.  



Lesions that arise from the interlobular stromal tissue include phyllodes tumor and fibroadenoma. Phyllodes tumor is an uncommon fibroepithelial breast tumor with a diverse biological manifestations ranging from benign fibroadenoma to distant metastasis. It accounts for less than 1% of all breast cancers and mostly occurs in women with a median age of 43 years.    



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Paget's disease of the breast is an extension of underlying ductal carcinoma in situ/invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts, and contiguous skin of the nipple. Patients typically present with eczematous patches over the nipple. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple. There is no breast cancer that arises from the skin of the nipple, and this patient’s presentation and histology results favor another diagnosis.   
❌ B:
Incorrect: The sinuses are an extension of the lactiferous duct and are the location in which milk accumulates. Clogged duct, galactocele, intraductal papilloma, abscess and mastitis may arise from this area. However, this patient’s presentation and histology results favor another diagnosis.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Terminal duct lobular units, also known as lobules, are epithelial structures within the breast that produce milk during lactation. These areas can give rise to conditions such as fibrocystic changes, lobular carcinoma in situ/invasive, and ductal carcinoma in situ/invasive. However, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.   
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a breast lump she felt while showering. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension, which is managed with lovastatin and hydrochlorothiazide, respectively. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a lump in the right upper quadrant of the right breast and a palpable axillary lymph node are noted. She is sent for a mammography, which reveals no abnormalities. Ultrasound is obtained and shows a mass lesion. Core needle biopsy reveals the following image:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a palpable, nontender breast mass, nontender lymph nodes, a negative mammogram, and an ultrasound revealing a mass, all of which raises suspicion for a breast malignancy. The biopsy results show a classic picture of cells that invaded the stroma aligned in a “single-file,” which is characteristic of invasive lobular carcinoma. While most tumors appear as a palpable mass or mammographic density, a subgroup of invasive lobular carcinomas do not, as seen here. This allows lobular carcinomas to be clinically occult and difficult to detect by imaging, which often results in a worse prognosis.  

Invasive lobular carcinoma arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and crosses the basement membrane into the stroma. It is the 2nd most common cause of invasive breast carcinomas and accounts for up to 15% of the cases. Morphologically, it consists of infiltrating cells similar to the tumor cells seen in lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Approximately one-third of women with LCIS eventually develop invasive carcinoma. Importantly, invasive carcinoma may arise secondary to LCIS in the same breast or in the contralateral breast, and therefore, bilateral imaging is indicated.   

In contrast to other types of breast cancer, which often metastasizes to the bone, brain and liver, invasive lobular carcinoma has a unique metastatic pattern, as it spreads to the cerebrospinal fluid, serosal surfaces, gastrointestinal tract, ovary, uterus, and bone marrow. The majority of lobular carcinomas express hormone (estrogen, progesterone) receptors, whereas HER2 overexpression is rare. Treatment usually conosist of clinical and radiologic follow-up, chemoprevention with tamoxifen or, less commonly, bilateral prophylactic mastectomy.  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  



Option Analysis

❌ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lactiferous duct and does not cross the basement membrane. DCIS typically produces calcifications which appear on mammography.  


Reproduced from: flickr
❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. However, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive ductal carcinoma is an invasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the ducts, and crosses the basement membrane into the stroma. However, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis. Additionally, similar to ductal carcinoma in situ, it usually appears as calcifications on mammography.  
✅ Invasive lobular carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Comedo carcinoma:
Incorrect: Comedo carcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ that is characterized by extensive central necrosis. Transected ducts produce cheese-like necrotic tissue that extrudes from the ducts when gentle pressure is applied to the breast. However, this patient’s mammography and histology results favor another diagnosis.
